Instrument.name: Mars Express Orbiter High Resolution Stereo Camera
Instrument.description: The High Resolution Stereo Camera (HRSC), originally developed for the Russian-led Mars-96 mission, was selected as part of the Orbiter payload for ESA's Mars Express (MEX) mission. The HRSC is a pushbroom scanning instrument with nine CCD line detectors mounted in parallel in the focal plane. Its unique feature is the ability to obtain near-simultaneous imaging data of a specific site at high resolution, with along-track triple stereo, four colours and five different phase angles, thus avoiding any time-dependent variations of the observational conditions. An additional Super-Resolution Channel (SRC) a framing device yields nested images in the metre-resolution range for detailed photogeologic studies. The spatial resolution from the nominal periapsis altitude of 250 km is 10 m px 1, with an image swath of 53 km, for the HRSC and 2.3 m px 1 for the SRC. The HRSC will close the gap between the medium-to-low resolution coverage and the very high-resolution images of the Mars Observer Camera on the Mars Global Surveyor mission and the in situ observations and measurements by landers. The HRSC contributes to the study of Martian geosciences, with special emphasis on the evolution of the surface in general, the evolution of volcanism, and the role of water throughout Martian history. The instrument obtains images containing morphologic and topographic information at high spatial and vertical resolution, allowing the improvement of the cartographic base down to scales of 1:50,000. The experiment addresses atmospheric phenomena and atmosphere-surface interactions, and will provide urgently needed support for current and future lander missions as well as for exobiological studies.
